Ribosomopathies refer to a group of diseases that are characterised by abnormalities in ribosomes, which are the organelles that synthesise proteins. Ribosomopathies can be divided into two main categories: disorders of ribosome biogenesis and disorders of ribosome function.
Disorders of ribosome biogenesis include Diamond-Blackfan anemia, Shwachman-Diamond syndrome, and 5q- syndrome. These disorders are characterised by defects in the production of ribosomes, which leads to decreased protein synthesis and a reduction in the number of functional red blood cells.
Disorders of ribosome function include myelodysplastic syndrome and Diamond-Blackfan anemia. These disorders are characterised by defects in the structure or function of ribosomes, which leads to impaired protein synthesis and a reduction in the number of functional red blood cells.
Ribosomopathies are typically associated with a high degree of cell and tissue specific pathology. For example, Diamond-Blackfan anemia is associated with a range of abnormalities including facial abnormalities, skeletal deformities, and deficiencies in red blood cells.
